revision.text:
'''Nationalization of history''' is the term used in [[historiography]] to describe the process of separation of "one's own" history from the common [[universal history]], by way of perceiving, understanding and treating the past that results with construction of history as history of a nation.<ref>{{cite book | last = Kas'yanov | first = Georgiy | authormask = | authorlink = |author2=Philipp Terr | firstn = | lastn = | authorn-link = | editor = | editorn-last = | editorn-first = | editor-link = | editorn-link = | others = | title = A Laboratory of Transnational History Ukraine and recent Ukrainian historiography |trans-title=| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=HjFjTRL5O_4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+Laboratory+of+Transnational+History+Ukraine+and+recent+Ukrainian+historiography&hl=en&ei=LXrITLPwGIuOjAeC7qnjCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false | format = | accessdate = October 18, 2010 | type = | edition = | series = | volume = | origyear = | year = 2009 | publisher = Central European University Press | location = Budapest, Hungary | isbn = 978-963-9776-26-5 | oclc = | doi = | bibcode = | id = | page = | pages = 7 | nopp = | at = | chapter = |trans-chapter=| chapterurl = | quote = This essay deals with, what I call, "nationalized history", meaning a way of perceiving, understanding and treating the past that requires separation of "one's own" history from "common" history and its construction as history of a nation. | ref = | laysummary = | laydate = | separator = | postscript = | lastauthoramp = }}</ref> If national labeling of the past is not treated with great care, it can result in the retrospective nationalization of history<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.luiss.it/mes/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/ceh-2003-36-n1-ther-beyond-the-nation-germany-and-europe.pdf | title = Beyond the Nation: The Relational Basis of a Comparative History of Germany and Europe | accessdate = October 18, 2010 | author = Philipp Terr | authorlink = Philipp Terr | pages = 57 | quote = "If a retrospective ethnicization or nationalization of history is to be avoided, any national labeling needs to be treated with great care."}}</ref> and even assigning nonexistent or exaggerating existing national attributes of historical events and persons. Nationalization of history, which began after a period of globalization of history, was not only one of causes, but also element and result of the process of establishment of modern [[nation]]s ([[Romantic nationalism|national revival]]).<ref>Kasianov, Terr, p. 7, "In some countries nationalization of history was part of "invention of tradition", while in others it was an element of so called "national renaissance" or "national awakening" ...</ref>
== Universal history == {{Main|Universal history}} [[File:Atelier de Nicolas de Largillière, portrait de Voltaire, détail (musée Carnavalet) -002.jpg|thumb|[[Voltaire]] was the first in the [[modern period]] who attempted to write a history of the world, without use of religious and nationalistic interpretations of the past.]] [[Universal history]], the result of a universal, cosmopolitan interpretation of historical events and mankind as a whole, coherent unit, preceded the nationalization of history. In the [[Western world]], this motivation to imagine a universal history became influential in the 18th century when numerous philosophers promoted new cosmopolitan ideologies,<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/2557562/History-of-Globalization | title = The History of Globalization - and the Globalization of History | accessdate = October 20, 2010 | author = A. G. Hopkins | authorlink = A. G. Hopkins | pages = 1 | quote = In the case of the Western world, the impulse to produce a universal history gained distinction and influence in the eighteenth century when the philosophers promoted a new, cosmopolitan ideology.}}</ref> after the ethno-religious conflicts of the previous century, and the subsequent consolidation of states which attempted to impose themselves over religious particularisms. Colonial experience (many [[Europe]]an countries had colonies) exposed society in Europe to numerous different cultures and civilizations. It is also very important to take in consideration that the 18th century was in the [[Age of Enlightenment]] when people's activities, both on individual and social level, were determined with desire to follow rational scientific judgment while changing the society, which released them from restraints of customs and arbitrary authorities based on [[faith]], [[superstition]], or [[revelation]] and backed up by [[religion]] or [[tradition]].<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://ieet.org/index.php/IEET/print/3641 | title = The enlightenment | accessdate = October 20, 2010 | author = Dorinda Outram | last = | first = | authorlink = | year = 1995 | format = | work = | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = | pages = | doi = | quote = Enlightenment was a desire for human affairs to be guided by rationality rather than by faith, superstition, or revelation; a belief in the power of human reason to change society and liberate the individual from the restraints of custom or arbitrary authority; all backed up by a world view increasingly validated by science rather than by religion or tradition.}}</ref> All these circumstances provided suitable surroundings for development of universalistic, liberal and rational global perspectives in studies of society and its past and writing historical texts.
In his ''Essay on customs (1756)'' [[Voltaire]] studied development of civilization in the world with universal perspective, rejecting tradition, Christian and national frames. He was significantly influenced by [[Jacques-Bénigne Bossuet]] and his work ''Discourse on the Universal history (1682)'' when he was first who seriously attempted to write a history of the world, without limits imposed by nation or religion, emphasizing economical, cultural and political history. [[Imanuel Kant]] developed ideas about universally applicable moral imperatives in his work ''Perpetual Peace (1795)'' and designed a plan for establishing a [[Cosmopolitanism|cosmopolitan]] liberal order which would result in perpetual [[peace]]. Universalism of the 18th century created an ideology which today could be identified as [[Civil society|modern civil society]].
The emerging of modern historiography is connected with German universities in the 19th century and the significant influence of [[Leopold von Ranke]] who insisted on objectivity and systematic use of historical documents in the form of authentic primary sources; his credo was to perform reconstruction of the past "as it was".<ref>A. G. Hopkins, p.2 "Leopold von Ranke founded historical research on the systematic use of documentary evidence, on reconstructing the past `as it was', and on the ideal of objectivity."</ref> Ranke's universal precepts in virtually all his works were, however, applied almost exclusively to the history of states and nations.<ref>A. G. Hopkins, p.2 " These were universal precepts. In practice, however, they were applied almost exclusively to the history of states and nation states in Europe,.... Virtually all of Ranke's own work,... was devoted to these themes."</ref>
== Causes of nationalization of history == Though nationalization of history could probably be traced from the earliest phases of creating historical works, it was in the period after the [[French revolution]] that creating of historical works started to be strongly influenced by national perspectives, and that perspective gradually became globally dominant with its culmination during the 19th and at the beginning of the 20th century. Nationalism was estimated as the proper perspective to such an extent that nationalization of history remained unnoticed till recently (1980s and 1990s) and was not studied in historiography in a scale that would correspond to its significance.
Many various reasons, depending on the circumstances, caused nationalization of history. Probably the most important is [[Romantic nationalism|national revival]], the important element of which was nationalized history,<ref>Kasianov, Terr; p. 7, "In some countries nationalization of history was part of "invention of tradition", while in others it was an element of so called "national renaissance" or "national awakening" .."</ref> that resulted in the emerging of modern [[nations]] and [[Nation state|nation-states]], mostly during the 19th century. With the emerging of national states, a global universal approach to writing history lost ground to the nation-state and was very much captured by it even in a significant part of the 20th century.<ref>A. G. Hopkins, p. 2 "Nevertheless, the cosmopolitan ideal lost ground to the nation state in the nineteenth century and for the greater part of the twentieth century too, and was to a large degree captured by it."</ref> [[Professionalization and institutionalization of history|The professionalization and institutionalization of history]] that took part in nation-states' institutions during the 19th and first half of the 20th century was closely connected with the process of history's increasing nationalization.<ref>{{cite web| url =http://www.uni-leipzig.de/zhsesf/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=107&Itemid=29| title =Writing the Nation - A Global Perspective (Stefan Berger)| first =| last =| author =Stefan Berger| authorlink =Stefan Berger| date =January 16, 2008| work =| publisher =European Science Foundation| location =| page =| pages =| at =| language =| trans-title =| format =| doi =| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20131213141742/http://www.uni-leipzig.de/zhsesf/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=107&Itemid=29| archivedate =2013-12-13| accessdate =October 29, 2010| quote =The institutionalization and professionalisation of history writing is analysed in the context of history's increasing nationalization in the course of the nineteenth and first half of the twentieth century.| ref =| separator =| postscript =| deadurl =yes| df =}}</ref> Nationalization of history was additionally entrenched by the development of national curricula in schools based on "monumental and prestigious" series of "authoritative" national stories, often written in insular style and justificatory manner.<ref>A. G. Hopkins, p. 2, "The tradition of writing national histories was further entrenched in the twentieth century through the development of national curricula in schools and the production of prestigious series, typically described as being `monumental' and `authoritative', that told the `national story' in an insular style and often in a justificatory manner."</ref>
[[File:German losses after WWI.svg|thumb|Germany after Versailles: {{legend|#ddefd0|Administered by the [[League of Nations]]}} {{legend|#ffffcf|Annexed or transferred to neighboring countries by the treaty, or later via plebiscite and League of Nation action}} {{legend|#f6d3a9|[[Weimar Republic|Weimar Germany]]}}]] After the [[First World War]] was finished, in some cases during establishment of new frontiers, the principle of national self-determination was taken in consideration during frontier [[Demarcation line|demarcation]]. Therefore, it was necessary to establish the national historical character of certain territories and settlements, like in case between Germany and Poland and the Versailles treaty when numerous historians prepared short studies in an attempt to support territory demands based on Germany or Poland.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.cliohres.net/books4/5/13.pdf | title = Frontiers, regions and identities in Europe | accessdate = October 18, 2010 | author = Steven G. Ellis and Raingard Eβer | last = | first = | authorlink = |author2=Jean-François Berdah |author3=Miloš Řezník | format = | work = | publisher = Directorate General for Research of the European Commission | location = | pages = | doi = | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110724113010/http://www.cliohres.net/books4/5/13.pdf | archivedate =2011-07-24 | dead-url = yes | quote = .... During the Versailles Conference, which was to settle the Polish-German frontier, both sides advanced historical arguments in support of their competing demands. Professional Polish and German historians, geographers and sociologists issued brief statements in English or French in order to achieve this..}}</ref>
After the [[Second World War]] and the process of [[decolonization]], the process of establishing new countries led to additionally stimulated nationalization of history because "new [[flags]] requested new histories".<ref>A. G. Hopkins, p.2 "This approach was adopted enthusiastically by the new states that came into being following the upheavals brought about by two world wars and decolonization. New flags required new histories."</ref> Even when citizens of newly-established countries already had their national identity built, the nationalization of history was aimed to create of new national identity based on citizenship. [[Canada]] is an example of an attempt at nationalization of history to create a shared, historically-rooted identity for English and French Canadians.<ref>{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=0xEvAQAAIAAJ&q=%E2%80%9EColony+to+nation%E2%80%9C+and+nationalization+of+the+history&dq=%E2%80%9EColony+to+nation%E2%80%9C+and+nationalization+of+the+history&hl=en&ei=cC7JTJh6yvGyBrHOrZIO&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAQ | title = America, history and life, tom 41, edition 2; Arthur R. M. Lower's "Colony to nation" and the nationalization of the history | accessdate = October 18, 2010 | author = | last = | first = | authorlink = | format = | work = | publisher = International journal of Canadian studies | location = | pages = | doi = | quote = Arthur R. M. Lowers „Colony to nation“ and nationalization of the history. International journal of Canadian studies, .....is one of the most popular Canadian history texts ever produced. It informed and educated generations of english Canadians with its exciting story of heroes and victims, triumphs and tragedies, and of colony that developed into a nation. It was more than historical text however. It was R.M. Lowers attempt to unite English and French Canadians in shared, historically rooted identity.}}</ref> Causes of nationalization of history in former communist regimes, mostly at the end of the 20th century, can be also found in reaction on long-term submission to communist historical interpretations and forced disregard for bourgeois nationalistic past.<ref>{{cite book | last = Pakier | first = Małgorzata | authormask = | authorlink = |author2=Bo Stråth | firstn = | lastn = | authorn-link = | editor = | editorn-last = | editorn-first = | editor-link = | editorn-link = | others = | title = A European Memory?: Contested Histories and Politics of Remembrance |trans-title=| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=f52rawP96lYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=A+European+Memory%3F:+Contested+Histories+and+Politics+of+Remembrance&hl=en&ei=cn3ITJWBMc2TjAfHyoA8&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false | format = | accessdate = | type = | edition = | series = | volume = | origyear = | publisher = Berghahn Books | location = United States | language = | isbn = 978-1-84545-621-4 | oclc = | doi = | bibcode = | id = | page = | pages = | nopp = | at = | chapter = |trans-chapter=| chapterurl = | quote = In Eastern Europe, the continuing nationalization of history can to a great extent be explained as a reaction against long-term submission to Soviet communist historical formulas and interpretations and against corresponding forced disregard for nationalistic or bourgeois nationalistic past ..... | ref = | laysummary = | laydate = | separator = | postscript = | lastauthoramp = }}</ref> In cases where one of the results of coloured revolutions (i.e. [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Ukraine]],...) was the desire to gain symbolic distance from a [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] past, the nationalization of history was a tool for externalizing of the communist past and rediscovery of European national identity of nation.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.eurozine.com/articles/2007-05-10-zhurzhenko-en.html | title = The geopolitics of memory | accessdate = October 19, 2010 | author = Tatiana Zhurzhenko | last = | first = | authorlink = | work = | publisher = Eurozine | location = | pages = | doi = | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070825174221/http://www.eurozine.com/articles/2007-05-10-zhurzhenko-en.html | archivedate =2007-08-25 | dead-url = yes | quote = In Ukraine and Georgia, the two post-Soviet countries in the "new" eastern Europe that experienced Coloured Revolutions, there are different reasons for the growing concern with historical memory......They distance themselves symbolically from the former empire by externalizing the communist past and by nationalizing historical memory....}}</ref>
== Renationalization of history == If the first phase of nationalization of history was forcibly suppressed by a national ideology ([[communism]]) or traumatic losing of wars ([[Japan]], [[Germany]], ...) there can be a second phase, [[renationalization of history]], on usually changed basis and perspective of nationalism.
=== Renationalization of history in Ukraine === The nationalization of history in [[Ukraine]] had two separate phases:<ref>Kasianov, Terr, p. 7, "Ukraine experienced nationalization of history in two stages. The first began in mid-nineteenth century and reached its heights in the creation of grand narrative, Mykhailo Hrushevsky's „History of Ukraine - Rus“. The tradition of historical writings that emerged at this stage persisted in Ukrainian Marxist historiography until the end of Second World War.... In diasporas historiography it turned it into canon, a true credo. The second stage began in 1980s and still continuing. .... It is taking place under state sponsorship and is integral part of nationalization of the state."</ref> * ''First phase'' began in the middle of the 19th century and reached its culmination in [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]]'s “History of Ukraine - Rus'”. This phase lasted till the end of the [[Second World War]] when it was stopped because of political changes in the Soviet Union, while in [[diasporas]] Hrushevsky's text had [[cult]] status. * ''Second phase'' started in the 1980s and still lasts as of 2010, as a consequence of direct state sponsorship becoming an integral part of nationalization of the state. At the beginning, it was not so intensive, but after its turning point on August 24, 1991, it achieved special purposes: to legitimize the newly established [[state (polity)|state]] and its governing elites, establishing territorial and chronological conceptions of the [[Ukrainian nation]], and to confirm the appropriateness of its existence as legal successor in the consciousness of its citizens and neighbours.<ref>Kasianov, Terr, p. 11, "Nationalized history began to fulfil important instrumental functions: legitimize newly established state and its attendant elite, establishing territorial and chronological conceptions of Ukrainian nation, and to confirm nations appropriateness of that nations existence as legal successor in the consciousness of its citizens and neighbours alike."</ref>
The irst phase chronologically coincided with the process of "rediscovery of tradition" and [[Romantic nationalism|national revival]] that captured all of Europe, while the second phase takes place in a period of globalization, vanishing cultural frontiers and aggressive international forms of [[mass culture]].<ref>Kasianov, Terr, p. 7,"... unlike the previous stage, that coincided with general European phenomenon of "invention of tradition" and the development of the nations, the present stage is unfolding in the era of globalization, fading the cultural boundaries and large-scale aggression of the international forms of mass culture."</ref>
== Legacy of nationalization of history == === Nation mythologies, histories and states === [[File:Crawfordkalevalahero1.jpg|thumb|right|150px|An ancient Finnish Hero – Illustration from [[Kalevala]]]] One of the most important consequences of [[publishing|printed]] [[literature|texts]] of nationalized history was that it provided a basis for [[Romantic nationalism|national revivals]] in the process of creating modern nations.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.nationalismproject.org/books/a_b.htm#Anchor-Anderson-23526 | title = Review of "Imagined Communities: Reflections on the Origin and Spread of Nationalism" by Benedict Anderson | accessdate = October 19, 2010 | author = E. Zuelow | last = | first = | authorlink = | year = 2001 | format = | work = | publisher = Verso | location = | pages = | doi = | quote = ... Anderson places print capitalism at the very heart of his theory, claiming that it was print capitalism which allowed for the development of these new national cultures and created the specific formations which the new nations would eventually take.}}</ref> Projects of national awakenings captured nationalized history and turned it into a weapon of popularization of [[national myth]]s in the period of establishing history as a social scientific discipline. A shortcut to production of national mythologies that proves ancient origins of modern nations, providing them with a respectable past, was [[forgery]] of historical documents, literature and historical works that were lost for some time, and then suddenly rediscovered to the approval of an astonished grateful [[public]]. Authors of such rediscovered treasures that were in a quest for [[Social status|success]] and glory did not suspect that they were in fact builders of as yet nonexistent modern [[nation]]s.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.nbuv.gov.ua/portal/Soc_Gum/eidos/2008_3/articles/188_Eidos-2008.pdf | title = Ukraine or Little Russia? Revisiting the Early Nineteenth -Century Debate | accessdate = October 19, 2010 | author = Serhii Plokhii | last = | first = | authorlink = Serhii Plokhii | format = | work = | publisher = | location = | pages = | doi = | quote = Historical writing was successfully taken over by national projects and turned into a vehicle for the popularization of national mythologies at a time when history was just beginning to establish itself as a scholarly discipline. A shortcut to the production of elaborate mythologies that “proved” the ancient origins of modern nations and provided them with respectable pasts was the forging of ancient documents and literary and historical works allegedly lost at some time and now “rediscovered” to the astonishment and approval of a grateful public. More often than not, the authors of such “rediscovered” treasures were in pursuit of literary success and/or money. They did not suspect that they were fulfilling a social demand, serving as agents of history, or acting as builders of as yet nonexistent modern nations.}}</ref> Even when it was obvious that certain texts were basically invented national myths, many social groups, and even intellectuals, wanted to believe that they were authentic national epics, like the [[Kalevala]] in [[Finland]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Dundes | first = Alan | authorlink = Alan Dundes | firstn = | lastn = | authorn-link = | title = Folklore Matters |trans-title=| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=cDPbnS8PjcMC&pg=PA46&dq=The+problem+was,+that+although+folklorist+knew+very+well+that+Kalevala+was+not+regular+folklore&hl=en&ei=0jDJTOj9IMeaOpnU-a8B&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=The%20problem%20was%2C%20that%20although%20folklorist%20knew%20very%20well%20that%20Kalevala%20was%20not%20regular%20folklore&f=false | accessdate = October 29, 2010 | year = 1989 | publisher = University of Tennessee Press | location = USA | isbn = 0-87049-608-5 | page = 46 | pages = | nopp = | quote = The problem was, that although folklorist knew very well that Kalevala was not regular folklore,... the Finnish people, including many intellectuals preferred to believe that Kalevala was genuine folk epic. }}</ref>
The nationalization of history, which had its origins more in the epics and tendentious [[Public speaking|oratory]] than in [[philosophy]], sometimes grew the idea of an ''esprit des peuples'' or ''national spirit'', and, later still, the idea that each nation had a 'mission'. Such ideas did not evolve into groups of associated individuals, but into universal spirits that is said to be able to destroy [[individuals]] and nations.<ref>{{cite book | last = Croce | first = Benedetto | authormask = | authorlink = Benedetto Croce | firstn = | lastn = | authorn-link = | editor = | editorn-last = | editorn-first = | editor-link = | editorn-link = | others = | title = My philosophy and other essays on the moral and political problems of our time |trans-title=| url = http://shawnslayton.com/open/books/Book%20My%20Philosophy%20great%20read.pdf | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110716052918/http://shawnslayton.com/open/books/Book%20My%20Philosophy%20great%20read.pdf | archivedate =2011-07-16 | format = pdf | accessdate = November 6, 2010 | type = | edition = | series = | volume = | origyear = 1949 | year = 1951 | publisher = Jas. Truscott and Son Ltd. | location = Great Britain | isbn = | oclc = | doi = | bibcode = | id = | page = | pages = | nopp = | at = | chapter = Denationalisation of history |trans-chapter=| chapterurl = | quote = The nationalisation of history had its origin in the epic character....... Later there grew up a bad philosophy which invented the idea of an esprit des peuples or 'national spirit', and, later still, the idea of the 'mission' of each nationality..... The fact is that what really evolves is not an individual or a group of associated individuals, but the universal spirit which by its spontaneous function, raises up and destroys individuals and nations for its own purpose. | ref = | laysummary = | laydate = | separator = | postscript = | dead-url = yes | lastauthoramp = }}</ref>
Nationalization of history was an important element of national revival and creating new [[nation states]] in the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century. New nation states and their institutions had the most important role in social process of [[Professionalization and institutionalization of history|the professionalization and institutionalization of history]] that was additionally supporting the process of nationalization of history. The final consequence was that national history regarded the nation-state as the primary unit of historical analysis.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://science.jrank.org/pages/7905/National-History.html | title = National history - Nation building and professionalization, varieties of national history, Germany, Britain, nation and history today | first = | last = | author = | authorlink = | work = | publisher = Science Encyclopedia | location = | page = | pages = | at = | language = |trans-title=| doi = | accessdate = October 29, 2010 | quote = National histories regard the nation-state as the primary unit of historical analysis | ref = | separator = | postscript = }}</ref>
=== Society and nature === [[File:Former Yugoslavia 2008.PNG|250px|thumb|State entities on the former territory of Yugoslavia, 2008.]] Nationalization of history affects all aspects of life, from relationships with other nationalities to [[architecture]]. This is a result of the fact that nationalization of history corresponds with nationalization of nature, and the fact that reservations and hostilities toward other nations accompanied [[nationalism]] from the beginning.<ref>{{Cite web| url =http://www.doaks.org/publications/doaks_online_publications/Nature/natur010.pdf| title =Nature and Ideology - Natural Garden Design in the Twentieth Century - The Nationalization of Nature and the Naturalization of the German Nation: "Teutonic" Trends in Early Twentieth-Century, Landscape Design| accessdate =18 October 2010| author =Joachim Wolschke-Bulmahn| last =| first =| authorlink =| format =| work =| publisher =Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection, Trustees for Harvard University| location =| pages =| doi =| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20101123234924/http://doaks.org/publications/doaks_online_publications/Nature/natur010.pdf| archivedate =2010-11-23| quote =The nationalization of history corresponded with a nationalization of nature. Nature became defined in national terms....Reservations about or even hostility toward other peoples were inherent elements of nationalism from the very beginning.| deadurl =yes| df =}}</ref> At the end of the 20th century there were extreme nationalistic interpretations of [[Balkan]] and [[Caucasus]] history, which became powerful weapons in ethno-territorial conflicts and accelerated disintegration of multinational states like [[Yugoslavia]] and the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>Pakier, Stråth; p. 39, "In the Balkan and Caucasian parts of Europe, history in extreme nationalistic interpretations developed into powerful weapon in ethno-territorial conflicts and accelerated disintegration of multi-national states like Soviet Union and Yugoslavia."</ref>
After disintegration of multinational states like [[Yugoslavia]] and [[Soviet Union]], besides the process of [[renationalization of history]], there is sometimes also retroactive [[nationalization of victims]] or tragedies of the people that in past lived in those states. According to new national historical [[narrative]]s, the reason for some people were the victims of certain tragedies was because they were of a certain nationality, for example the [[Ukrainians]] of the [[Soviet Union]].<ref>Zhurzhenko, The geopolitics of memory, " An important consequence of the delegitimization of the Soviet historical narrative and the (re-)construction of national histories after 1991 is the retroactive [[nationalization of victims]]....According to the new national historical narrative, they were killed by the Soviet regime because they were Ukrainians"</ref> Nationalist discourse in [[Croatia]] presents the [[Bleiburg tragedy]] as an event where only [[Croatians]] suffered and died just because they were Croatians, eluding the fact that many of the victims were [[Serbs]], [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrins]] or [[Slovenians]] while many [[Croatians]] had died while fighting as collaborators against [[Partisans (Yugoslavia)|Yugoslav partisans]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/2008_822-16h_Pavlakovic.pdf | title = Red stars, black shirts: Symbols, commemorations, and contested histories of World War Two in Croatia | first = Vjeran | last = Pavlaković | date = 11 September 2008 | publisher = The National Council for Eurasian and East European Research | location = 2601 Fourth Avenue, Suite 310, Seattle, WA 98121, USA | page = 35 | language = Croatian | quote = Bleiburg, for example, is a place of exclusively of Croat suffering in the narrative constructed through the commemorations held there, even though Serbs, Slovenians, Montenegrins, and even Russians were among those killed by revengeful Partisans. Yet the nationalist discourse depicts a version of the past in which the victims died only because they were Croats, obscuring the fact that many of them had died in battle as part of collaborationist armed forces.}}</ref>
=== Denationalization of history === Nationalization of history has been increasingly called into question,<ref>{{cite book | last = Cronin | first = Michael | authormask = | authorlink = Michael Cronin (academic) | title = Translation and identity | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=RsRKWSwp3CcC&pg=PA22&dq=%22nationalization+of+history%22&hl=en&ei=exLUTIsfje6yBrrgzPME&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFMQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=%22nationalization%20of%20history%22&f=false | accessdate = November 5, 2010 | year = 2006 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York, USA | isbn = 0-415-36464-7 | oclc = | doi = | bibcode = | id = | page = 22 | pages = | nopp = | at = | chapter = Translation and the new cosmopolitanism |trans-chapter=| chapterurl = | quote = Increasingly, this nationalization of history has been called into question and a historian, such as [[Christopher Bayly|Christopher Alan Bayly]] ... argues that all local, national or regional histories must, in important ways, therefore, be global histories. | ref = | laysummary = | laydate = | separator = | postscript = | lastauthoramp = }}</ref> and one of its consequences is the emerging of processes of denationalization of history, which is the result of an intention to change the perspective of creating works about history by promoting [[Epistemological pluralism|pluralism]] and international standards in [[social science]]s.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://civiceducationproject.org/legacy/aboutus/newsletter/new0051.html | title = Writing and Rewriting History at the Turn of the Centuries | accessdate = October 18, 2010 | author = Aileen Rambow | last = | first = | authorlink = | work = | publisher = Civic Education Project (CEP) | location = | pages = | doi = | quote = The last panel "Rewriting National Histories—The [[Denationalization of history|De-Nationalization of History]]" offered various models of diversifying the writing of history.}}</ref> In [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]] there are tensions between nationalization of history and the process of European integrations.<ref>{{cite book | last = Iordachi | first = Constantin | authorlink = | title = "Entangled histories", Re-writing the history of Central and South-eastern Europe from Relational perspective |trans-title=| url = http://www.cees-europe.fr/fr/etudes/revue4/r4a5.pdf | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20041219045758/http://www.cees-europe.fr/fr/etudes/revue4/r4a5.PDF | archivedate =2004-12-19 | format = | accessdate = October 18, 2010 | page = 3 | dead-url = yes | quote = As a result of this twofold development, we can identify underlying tension between the "re-nationalization" of the history in Central and Southeast Europe and process of European integration. }}</ref> That is one of reasons for organized activities aimed toward denationalization of history.
In cases when history was reinterpreted and filtered by the media and official orthodoxy there is a situation in which nationalization of history leads to its denial.<ref>{{cite book | last = Michel | first = Le Gall | authormask = | authorlink = |author2=Kenneth J. Perkins | firstn = | lastn = | authorn-link = | editor = | editorn-last = | editorn-first = | editor-link = | editorn-link = | others = | title = The Maghrib in question: essays in history & historiography |trans-title=| url = | format = | type = | edition = | series = | volume = | year = 1977 | publisher = University of Texas Press | location = | language = | isbn = 0-292-76576-2 | oclc = | doi = | bibcode = | id = | page = 147 | pages = | nopp = | at = | chapter = Scholars and politicians |trans-chapter=| chapterurl = | quote = For as the countrie's history was reinterpreted and filtered by the media and the official orthodoxy, ... There was perfect example of the perverse effect analyzed by Raymond Boudon, in which the nationalization of history leads to its denial.. | ref = | laysummary = | laydate = | separator = | postscript = | lastauthoramp = }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Historiography and nationalism]] * [[National mysticism]]

'''Pedro Chirino''' (1557 – September 16, 1635) was a Spanish priest and historian who served as a Jesuit missionary in the [[Philippines]].<ref>Geoff Wade, [https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&se=gglsc&d=5000215857 "On the Possible Cham Origin of the Philippine Scripts"], ''Journal of Southeast Asian Studies'', vol 24 (1993)<!-- ISSN/ISBN needed --></ref> He is most remembered for his work, ''Relación de las Islas Filipinas'' (1604),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mts.net/~pmorrow/baynotes.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418131638/http://www.mts.net/~pmorrow/baynotes.htm |archivedate=2007-04-18 |df= }} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gutenberg.org/etext/15022|title=The Philippine Islands, 1493-1898 — Volume 12 of 55 by Bourne, Blair, and Robertson|website=Gutenberg.org|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chirino|first=Pedro|title=Relacion de las Islas Filipinas: Lihim Na Pagsamba Sa Diwata Sa Taytay|year=1604|url=http://www.elaput.org/chirn22.htm|website=Elaput.org|accessdate=2007-03-16}}</ref> one of the earliest works about the Philippines and its people that was written.
He was born in 1557 in the town of [[Osuna]] in [[Andalusia]], [[Spain]]. A graduate in both civil and canon laws at Sevilla, he entered the Society of Jesus at age 23. He was soon appointed to the mission in the Philippines, arriving in the country in 1590 along with [[Gómez Pérez Dasmariñas|Gomez Perez Dasmariñas]], the newly-appointed [[Governor-General of the Philippines|governor-general of the Philippines]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://kahimyang.info/kauswagan/articles/1619/today-in-philippine-history-september-16-1635-father-pedro-chirino-died-in-manila|title=Today in Philippine history: September 16, 1635, Father Pedro Chirino died in Manila|accessdate=August 30, 2017|website=The Kahimyang Project}}</ref>
He was first assigned to [[Balayan, Batangas|Balayan]] before he was appointed to be the parish priest of the town of [[Taytay, Rizal|Taytay]] in 1591. During his tenure as parish priest, he transferred the location of Taytay parish from its original site near [[Laguna de Bay]] to a hilltop area where it has remained to this day. He also began to immerse himself in the study of the Tagalog language and was able to preach his homily in Tagalog for the first time on August 15, 1591 on the occasion of the establishment of a Jesuit mission in Antipolo.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Lakbay-Pananampalataya|last=Fernandez|first=Jose|publisher=St John the Baptist Parish, Taytay, Rizal|year=2013}}</ref>
Chirino also went to missions in [[Tigbauan, Iloilo|Tigbauan]] from February 1593 to April 1595 and [[Leyte]] in June 1595. It was in Tigbauan where Father Chirino established in 1593 what would become the first Jesuit boarding-school in the Philippines.<ref name=":1"/>
In the course of his missionary work, Father Chirino also recorded the transition of Filipino writing from the [[Baybayin]] script to the Latin alphabet.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mts.net/~pmorrow/bayeng1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rpLR9aNS?url=http://www.mts.net/~pmorrow/bayeng1.htm |archivedate=2010-08-08 |df= }} </ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bibingka.com/dahon/literacy/literacy.htm|title=Bibingka|website=Bibingka.com|accessdate=30 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070407094947/http://www.bibingka.com/dahon/literacy/literacy.htm|archivedate=7 April 2007|df=}}</ref> In addition, he began writing down his knowledge of Philippine history as well as his observations on the way of life of Filipinos in that period. Upon his return to Europe in 1602, he worked on the publication of these writings into a book entitled ''Relación de las Islas Filipinas''. The book was eventually published in [[Rome]] in 1604.{{cn|date=August 2017}}
In Europe, he was able to further establish the Jesuit mission in the Philippines at both the royal and pontifical courts. Through his efforts, he was able to obtain a decree from the [[Superior General of the Society of Jesus]], elevating the Philippine mission to the status of vice-province, independent of the province of Mexico.<ref name=":0"/>
Father Chirino returned to the Philippines in 1606 and continued writing about the Philippines; many of these writings have yet to be published. He died in Manila on September 16, 1635.<ref name=":0"/>

[[Image:Grotepier TN.JPG|180px|thumb|Statue of [[Pier Gerlofs Donia]]. Famous rebel and freedom fighter of legendary strength and size of whom Thaborita wrote]] '''Petrus Jacobi Thaborita''' ([[List of Latinised names|Latinised]] name form of '''Peter Jacobusz van Bolsward''') ([[Bolsward]], 1450–1527) was a [[Frisia]]n [[monk]], [[historian]] and [[writer]]. He is best known for his writings on the [[Frisians|Frisian]] [[freedom fighter]] [[Pier Gerlofs Donia]], and for writing down Donia's [[last words]]. In the extended works by Thaborita van Bolsward is found information on the Frisian chieftains warlords [[Jancko Douwama]] and [[Haring Harinxma]] (the [[Donia family|Donia]] ancestor). Dutch writer [[Conrad Busken Huet]] used many of Thaborita's descriptions of historical figures in later books. He also translated the description of Donia. Thaborita joined the monastery at an advanced age, as a widower with two sons. Petrus also dedicated a chapter in one of his books{{specify|date=August 2012}} to Donia:
'''About the death of Greate Pier, [[Pier Gerlofs Donia]]:
''' "''In dat selue iaer van 20 soe is ghestoruen groet Pyer, op Sinte Lucas nacht. Van deese Pier was grote spraeck in Hollant, in Brabant ende in ander landen, van sin grote stercheit ende gruwelicheit, ende van sin grote oghen; ende sy maectent groter dant was; mer noch tans wasset een groet, swaert, man mit grote oghen, grote schouwer ende een groten baert, ende gruweliken van aensyen, sonderlingh als hy toernich was; ende hy was grof ende plompt van spraeck ende wesen; want hy en conste nyet bequam spreken voert recht ofte voer heeren; mer mit sin groue Fryesche slaghen quaem hy mede vort, ende dat ghyngh hem alsoe plomp of, dat alle menschen, die daer by stonden, worden beweghen tot lachgen; ende hy was froem ende fel op die vianden, mer hy was redelyk van herten als een Kersten man.''"
'''English translation''': "''In the very same year of 1520, on Saint Lucas night, [[Grutte Pier]] died. Of this Pier in Holland, in Brabant and other countries tales went around about his strength and his brutality and about his large eyes. And they made it bigger than it was. Yet he was a big, heavy man, with big eyes, broad shoulders and a big beard and terrible of appearance especially when he was angry. And he was rude and unarticulated of speech and manners. Because he wasn't able to speak properly in court or in front of lords. He often made jokes, so that all the people standing around, were made to laugh. He had killed many enemies, but he had a rather good character, as if he were a good Christian.''"{{cn|date=June 2015}}
[[Anton Reinhard Falck]] was the owner of the original documents, he lent these to the researchers Visser and Amersfoordt.{{cn|date=June 2015}} ==References== *"Archief voor Vaderlandse en ingezonderheid Vriesche geschiedenis, oudheid- en taalkunde" by H.W.C.A. Visser and H. Amersfoordt, part one printed by G.T.N. Suringar, Leeuwarden,1824 and part two printed by H.C. Schetsberg, Leeuwarden, 1827. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thaborita, Petrus}} [[Category:1450 births]] [[Category:1527 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch historians]] [[Category:Frisian writers]] [[Category:People from Bolsward]]

{{Serer religion}} The '''Serer creation myth''' is the traditional [[creation myth]] of the [[Serer people]] of [[Senegal]], the [[Gambia]] and [[Mauritania]]. Many Serers who adhere to the tenets of the [[Serer religion]] believe these narratives to be [[sacred]]. Some aspects of Serer religious and [[Ndut initiation rite|Ndut traditions]] are included in the narratives contained herein but are not limited to them.
The Serer people have many [[:Category:Serer deities|gods]], [[goddess]]es<ref name="Kellog">{{en icon}} Kellog, Day Otis, and Smith, William Robertson, "The Encyclopædia Britannica: latest edition. A dictionary of arts, sciences and general literature", Volume 25, p. 64, Werner (1902)</ref> and ''[[Pangool]]'' (the [[Reincarnation#Serer religion|Serer saints and ancestral spirits]] represented by [[snake]]s),<ref>Gravrand, Henry, "La Civilisation Sereer - ''Pangool''", pp. 180, 305–402</ref> but one supreme deity and [[creator god|creator]] called [[Roog (Serer deity)|Roog]] (or Koox in the [[Cangin languages]]<ref name="Noon">{{fr icon}} Ndiaye, Ousmane Sémou, "Diversité et unicité sérères : l’exemple de la région de Thiès", Éthiopiques, no. 54, vol. 7, 2e semestre 1991 [http://ethiopiques.refer.sn/spip.php?page=imprimer-article&id_article=1253]</ref>).
Serer creation myth developed from Serer [[oral tradition]]s, [[Serer religion]], [[legend]]s, [[cosmogony|cosmogonies]].<ref name="Pangool pp 125-6"/><ref name="Thiaw myth"/> The specifics of the myth are also found in two main Serer sources: ''A nax'' and ''A leep''. The former is a short narrative for a short [[myth]] or [[proverbial expression]], whilst the later is for a more developed myth.<ref name="Pangool pp 193-4"/> Broadly, they are equivalent to [[verb]]s and [[logos]] respectively{{clarify|date=October 2013}}, especially when communicating fundamental [[religious education]] such as the supreme being and the [[Creation myth|creation of the Universe]]. In addition to being [[worldview|fixed]]-Serer sources, they set the structure of the myth.<ref name="Pangool pp 193-4"/>
The creation myth of the Serer people is intricately linked to [[Tree worship|the first trees]] created on [[earth|Planet Earth]] by Roog. Earth's formation began with a [[swamp]]. The Earth was not formed until long after the creation of the first three worlds: the [[cosmic ocean|waters]] of the [[underworld]]; the [[air]] which included the higher world (i.e. the [[sun]], the [[moon]] and the [[star]]s) and earth. Roog is the creator and fashioner of the Universe and everything in it. The creation is based on a mythical [[cosmic egg]] and the [[chaos (cosmogony)|principles of chaos]].<ref name="Thiaw myth"/><ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/>
==Common elements== There are slightly different and competing versions of the myth. However, there are more similarities than differences, and the differences complement each other in the greater understanding of Serer creation mythology.<ref name="Pangool pp 125-6"/><ref name="Thiaw myth"/> They all posits that, [[the Universe]] and everything in it were created by ''Roog'' (or ''Koox'' among the [[cangin languages|Cangin]]), and the creation of Planet Earth was a result of a [[swamp]] which the first tree grew within. The first three worlds created through a [[cosmic egg|mythical egg]] and under the principles of chaos were: the waters of the [[underworld]], the air including the higher world and earth. These three were the first [[cosmogony|primordial worlds]] created by the supreme being through ''thought'', ''speech'' and ''action''. Planet Earth was not created until long after the creation of these worlds. The contentious points are, which of the main sacred trees in Serer society (below) grew not just first, but also within the [[Abiogenesis|primordial swamp on Earth]]: :1. Saas (var: ''Sas'') - [[Faidherbia albida|Acacia albida]]<ref name="Nqaul"/> :2. Nquƭ (var: ''Ngud''<ref name="Thiaw myth"/> or ''NGuƭ''<ref name="Kal"/>) - [[Guiera senegalensis]]<ref name="Thiaw myth"/><ref name="Kal"/> :3. Somb - [[Prosopis africana]]<ref name="Nqaul"/><ref name="Kal"/> a species of [[Prosopis]] :4. Nqual (var: ''Ngaul''<ref name="Nqaul"/> or ''NGawal''<ref name="Kal"/>) - [[Mitragyna inermis]] part of [[Rubiaceae]] family of the genus [[Mitragyna]]<ref name="Nqaul"/><ref name="Kal"/> :5. Mbos - [[Gardenia|Gardenia ternifolia]]<ref name="Thiaw myth"/> The importance of these trees are crucial to the formation of Earth, at least in the Serer [[worldview]] and their genesis are addressed in their relevant sections. Being the first tree does not necessarily equate to being the first living thing on Earth. In the creation myth, animals such as the [[jackal]], [[hyena]], the [[snake|serpent]] and [[ostrich]] figure prominently in the competing creation narrative. In some narratives, trees and animals merge in order to justify their legitimacy. These mythical animals may be seen as [[sacred]] and [[totems]], in the [[Serer religion#Family totems|Serer totemic]] and [[Sentience|sentient]] worldly-view of [[animal]]s and [[nature]] in general. The significance of trees in the Serer creation myth does not mean the dwelling place of the supreme deity, neither do they mean the dwelling place of the [[devil]]. They are dwelling places for the sanctified ancestral spirits (''Pangool''). The [[Tree worship|cult of the tree]] is [[Religious symbolism|symbolic]] in [[Serer religion]].<ref name="Thiaw myth"/> The [[Femininity|feminine world]] also played a crucial role in the creation process of the [[Universe]] and the first-[[human]]s.<ref name="Thiaw myth"/><ref name="Pangool pp 193-4">Gravrand, "Pangool", pp. 193−4</ref> This is linked to the [[Serer philosophy of beauty]]<ref>{{fr icon}} Faye, Amade, " La beaute Seereer : Du modele mythique au motif poetique", [in] Ethiopiques, n° 68, revue négro-aricaine de littérature et de philosophie (1er semestre 2002) [http://ethiopiques.refer.sn/spip.php?page=imprimer-article&id_article=288]</ref> and Serer-[[number]]s found in [[Religious symbolism|Serer religious symbolism]], with ''[[number 3]]'' symbolizing the feminine world,<ref name="Pangool pp 193-4"/> ''[[number 4]]'' the [[Masculinity|masculine world]] and ''[[number 7]]'' (3 + 4) representing [[Balance (metaphysics)|balance]] and perfection, something the Serers try to achieve in their daily lives and the environment they find themselves in.<ref name="Pangool pp 457-8"/>
Before the existence of the Universe, Roog existed by itself.<ref name="Gravrand, Pangool, p 189">Gravrand, "Pangool", p 189</ref> There was nothing but silence and darkness.<ref name="Gravrand, Pangool, p 189"/> The Serer notion of balance and perfection illustrates the creation of the higher spiritual order and corresponds to the [[motif (literature)|motif]] of [[chaos (cosmogony)|chaos]]. Its creation was the union of male and female principles, with Roog, the supreme [[Transcendentals|transcendental]] principle entity, becoming the embodiment of an androgynous Godfather and Godmother. However, it is from the female component of the supreme being: ''"Noo tiig tew"'' (''"out of a female [[womb]]"'' - [[EXIT procedure|ex utero]]), that the divine brought forth the ancestors of modern humans, with a ''[[female]]'', being the first to be created.<ref name="Gravland in">{{en icon}} ([[Henry Gravrand]], "La civilisation Sereer -''Pangool''") [in] [[Universität Frankfurt am Main]], Frobenius-Institut, Deutsche Gesellschaft für Kulturmorphologie, Frobenius Gesellschaft, "Paideuma: Mitteilungen zur Kulturkunde, Volumes 43−44", F. Steiner (1997), pp 144-5, {{ISBN|3515028420}}</ref> There was a [[logos|mythical speech]] − the first [[word]][s] uttered by the supreme being. All the competing versions attest to that. This myth is the general consensus and represents the [[Universality (philosophy)|absolute truth]] in Serer primordial time.<ref name="Gravland in"/> A major competing myth, also based on chaos, postulates that, there was originally a series of explosions. However, it agrees pretty much with the accepted view that trees and animals were the first to be created.<ref name="Nia"/> Explosion first arose in the vegetable kingdom and the first tree ''Somb'', according to this myth, bursted, which the seeds of all the [[plant species]] in the world sprang out (from its trunk) covering [[Earth|Planet Earth]] with life.<ref name="Nia">{{fr icon}} + {{en icon}} Niangoran-Bouah, Georges, "L'univers Akan des poids à peser l'or : les poids dans la société", Les nouvelles éditions africaines - MLB, (1987), p. 25, {{ISBN|2723614034}}</ref> In all versions, Roog appears as both the [[creator god|creator]] and [[demiurge]].
==Cosmogony== Serer [[cosmogony]] is not as rich as the [[Dogon people|Dogon]]'s. [[Religious persecution#Persecution of the Serers|Religious and ethnic persecution of the Serers]] for several centuries had resulted in their migration to and fro. In spite of [[Serer history (medieval era to present)|this turbulent history]], the Serer people have the richest cosmogony of all the [[:Category:Senegambian languages|Senegambian ethnic groups]].<ref name="Pangool, pp 125-6">[[Henry Gravrand|Gravrand, Henry]], "La Civilisation Sereer - ''Pangool''", vol. 2. Les Nouvelles Editions Africaines du Senegal (1990), pp. 125−6, {{ISBN|2-7236-1055-1}}</ref>
===Creation of the Universe=== ====A nax and A leep==== The Serers relates the creation myth and the role of [[speech]] in the [[creation myth|formation of the Universe]]. Two Serer terms expresses the mythical creation word: ''"A nax"'' and ''"A leep"''. The former is a short narrative for a shorth myth or [[Proverbial phrase|proverbial expression]] and is equivalent to a [[verb]]. The later (''A leep'') is more advance and details the [[logos|mythical creation word]] and the creation itself, introducing the myth with the phrase: ''"Naaga reetu reet"'' (so it was in the beginning), before narrating the event. From a global perspective, the two roughly corresponds to [[verb]] and [[logos]], especially when communicating fundamental [[religious education]] relating to the supreme deity and the [[Creation myth|creation of the Universe]].<ref name="Pangool pp 193-4"/> They form the structure and sources under which the creation narrative is based.<ref name="Pangool pp 193-4"/> ''"A leep"'', the logos, is [[World view|fixed]].<ref name="Pangool pp 193-4"/>
The creation of the Universe is based on several parts (see below): :1. the structure which sets the basis of the narrative and the significance of the mythical word cited ::by the supreme being (see above); :2. the creation process based on Serer-numbers; :3. the [[Abiogenesis|genesis]] of the Universe; :4. the [[prologue]] of the primordial myth based on three key elements: water, air and earth; :5. the [[Cosmic ocean|primordial ocean]] and the formation of Planet Earth; :6. the [[rotation]]al motion around the [[Axis mundi|axis of the world]], the creation of [[tree]]s and [[Vegetation|plant life]]; :7. the creation of [[animals]]; :8. the creation of [[human]]s and the first male and female couple whose children and descendants went on to populate the world; :9. the crisis that befell Planet Earth and the separation of man and animal, and why the [[dog]] became man's friend; :10. intervention of [[Roog (Serer deity)|Roog]] and the process of [[Divine providence|divine intervention]] in the various stages of the creation and after the initial disorder; :11. Serer representation of the Universe – the three worlds: the [[Invisibility|invisible]] world [[Galaxy|from above]], the [[Diurnality|diurnal]] terrestrial world and the [[nocturnal]] world.<ref>Gravrand, "Pangool", pp. 194−218</ref>
====Process of the creation (Serer-number 3)==== The source of the Universe is attributed to the feminine and maternal nature of Roog. In [[Religious symbolism|Serer symbolism]], the ''number 3'' is attributed to the feminine world. This number is the ingredient of the creation process. There were three [[Dietary mineral|essential elements]], three parts of the [[cosmos]] and three worlds.<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/> This triple [[rhythm]] of Roog and the cosmos is also found in women as the Serer myth relates it: :"Roog a binda adna noo tiig tew'' (Roog has created the world of its feminine nature).<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/>" The phrase ''"Tiig Tew"'' is attributed to the feminine body of [[motherhood]] and is equivalent to the general [[saying]] of [[Mother goddess#Earth Mother|Mother Earth]].<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/> The phrase ''"No tiig tew"'' translates to ''"out of a female womb"'' - [[EXIT procedure|ex utero]].<ref name="Gravland in"/> The language here is symbolic.<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/> The Serer religion and oral tradition confers to Roog some rather realistic aspects of the initial creation. There were three phases in the [[gestation]] of the creatures within the devine being: ::1. by ''thought'' - within the living [[World egg|divine egg]], Roog developed the forms and beings to create. It laid the foundations and signs for things to come.<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/> ::2. by ''word'' - Roog started the [[gestation period]] and provided everything by word for the smooth realization of its plan.<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/> ::3. by ''action'' - through its maternal nature, Roog opened-up and projected the [[embryo]] and [[placenta]] in a similar fashion as in [[childbirth]].<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5"/> Roog did not create, nor did it engender all [[beings]] of all kinds. It simply created the [[archetype]]s, not the [[prototype]] of each [[species]], but seven archetypes namely '':''' the three essential elements (air, earth and water) and the top four [[seed]]s (the first tree, first animal and the first human couple - female, then male<ref name="Thiaw myth"/>).<ref name="Pangool pp 194-5">Gravrand, "Pangool", pp 194-5</ref><ref name="Gravland in"/>
====Genesis of the Universe (mythical words)==== The genesis of the Universe is found in ''"A nax"'' and ''"A leep"''. Which posits that: "In [[Cosmogony|the beginning]], there was [[nothing]] but [[darkness]] and [[silence]] until the pre-existent being, Roog, began the genesis of the [[world]]<ref name="Pangool pp 195-6">Gravrand, "Pangool", pp. 195−6</ref>" [the [[Universe]]<ref>The original source says ''"Adna fee"'', which translates to the [[Universe]], see: {{fr icon}} Kalis, Simone, "Médicine traditionnelle religion et divination chez les Seereer Siin du Senegal", ''La connaissance de la nuit'', L'Harmattan (1997), p 293, {{ISBN|2-7384-5196-9}}</ref>]. The Serer oral tradition does not speak of Roog's gestation, probably due to cultural [[taboo]], but only when the mythical word was uttered and what was uttered by the supreme being, which is found in ''A nax''. According to ''A nax'', the first mythical words spoken by Roog were: {{cquote|WATER! AIR! EARTH! <ref name="A nax">«''A nax''» [in] Gravrand, "Pangool", p. 195</ref>}} ''A leep'' details the scene of the primordial time in the following terms: :"A leep à joon maaga :a roxondox o maaga, :a gad'wa roog, :a saay'a lang ke."<ref name="A leep">«''A leep''» [in] Gravrand, "Pangool", p. 195</ref>
Which translates to: :The Words leap into [[space]], :He carried the [[Cosmic ocean|sea]] on his head, :the [[firmament]] on his shoulders, :the earth in his hands.<ref name="A leep"/>
The mythical words established the three worlds (water, air and earth) based on the [[prologue]] of the Serer genesis provided by ''A nax''.<ref name="Pangool pp 195-6"/> In ''A leep'', it gives the order in which they were created and elaborated on it. ''A leep'' posits that, with the words of Roog, the three worlds (the [[Universe]]) began to take shape. The first to be created was the deep sea waters (waters of the [[underworld]]); the second was [[air]] including the high heavens (''Kuul na'', in [[Serer language|Serer]]) such as the [[sun]], the [[moon]] and the [[stars]]; and third was earth. However, the [[Earth]] was not one of the first primordial worlds to be formed. It will take a long time before the waters and the Earth were separated.<ref>« ''A leep'' » [in] Gravrand, "Pangool", pp. 195−6</ref>
====First swamp and creation of Earth (''Nqaul'')==== The creation of [[Earth|Planet Earth]] is based on the myth of ''Nqaul'' (a type of tree - ''mitragyna inermis'').<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7">Gravrand, Pangool, pp. 196−7</ref> In this myth, the formation of the Earth was started by a [[swamp]].<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> Swamps are integral to [[:Category:Serer culture|Serer culture and traditions]] and have parallels with this Nqaul. The foundation of Serer villages, towns, homes, etc., in many cases, began with a swamp, even today.<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> ''Nqaul'' is also significant in the [[Timeline of Serer history|history of the Serers]]. At a time when [[rainfall]] were plentiful, during the rainy season, the [[States headed by ancient Serer Lamanes|founders of ancient Serer villages and towns]] were often surprise when the first rainfalls brought [[flood]]ing (see [[Saltigue]]).<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> [[Radiocarbon dating#Calibration|Calibrated]] archaeological dating have shown that, many of the places they had chosen to settle next to were [[shoal]]s.<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/><ref>Descamps, Cyr, "Contribution a la Préhistoire de l'Ouest-sénégalais, thèse, Paris, p. 315. (inédit : unpublished version, p 126)</ref><ref>Burke, Andrew, & Else, David, "The Gambia & Senegal", 2nd edition - September 2002, Lonely Planet Publications Pty Ltd, p 13</ref> Serer tradition states, on one occasion, the flooding caused severe damage resulting in many people losing their homes, crops and food they had [[farming|farmed]]. After the damage, the people who escaped returned to assess the damage and commiserated each other. They recalled an ancient myth − the myth of ''Nqaul'':<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> :''"Ko adoox a adax Nqaul"'' (You start like the beginning of Nqaul).<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> This phrase evokes the [[Abiogenesis|primordial swamp]] and the ''Nqaul'' tree which grew within the original swamp.<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> This tradition is still retained by the Serers as the [[saying]] is so widespread in [[:Category:Serer country|Serer country]].<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> It is a different kind of tree to ''Saas'' ([[Faidherbia albida|acacia albida]]).<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> Whilst some Serer sources postulates that the ''Saas'' was the first tree on Earth, the Serer oral tradition states that the ''Saas'' was not ''Nqual'' (the original tree in the swamp). Instead, ''Saas'' is attributed to one of the sacred trees useful for overall-bodily [[health]].<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/> Another sacred tree − the ''Nquƭ'', is also thought to have been the first tree. However, the general consensus is that the ''Nquƭ'' which has the properties to cure [[snakebite]] grew on the [[river bank]] whilst ''Nqual'' grew inside the primordial swamp.<ref name="Pangool pp 196-7"/>
====Rotational movement around the axis of the world==== {{further|Serer religion#Serer cosmology}} According to the Serer narrative, this initial [[islet]] was not static, but animated by a whirl around the [[Axis mundi|axis of the world]]. The Serers were able to symbolize the Earth's axis and the whirl in a [[geometric]]al diagram. In [[Serer religion#Serer cosmology|Serer cosmology]], the diagram depicts two crossed lines representing the rotational motion and the [[Line-line intersection|intersection]] points representing the axis of the world. One of the lines depicts the axis running from [[east]] to [[west]], the other from [[north]] to [[south]]. Simultaneously, they are the [[empyrean|Empyrean Heaven]] where the supreme deity is said to have given way to the first elements. In the myth, Roog is portrayed as the mythical deity who somehow "turned its self on". As the deity rotate in space, its rapid motions [[Metric expansion of space|expanded]] with the primordial world it had first created.<ref name="Pangool pp 197-8">Gravrand, "Pangool", pp. 197−8</ref> Roog's motion also affected the axis of the [[cosmos]]. The [[Physical cosmology#Energy of the cosmos|vital energies]] it had emitted, rotated in a [[spiral]] motion thereby creating the [[Astronomical object|celestial objects]].<ref name="Pangool pp 197-8"/>
Since the time of the [[States headed by ancient Serer Lamanes|ancient Serer Lamanes]], the Serer people have represented the axis of the world in the form of a [[stele]], symbolizing the steles of Roog.<ref name="Pangool pp 197-8"/> In the Serer home, sometimes in the courtyard, they represent the most sacred place of the house servicing as the [[centre of gravity]] of [[divine|divine energies]] and one of the [[Earth|pole]]s of the [[cosmogony|coronation]]. In the home, these steles are made of wooden slabs, forming a [[Sacred grove|sacred wood]]. Sometimes they are raised steles supported by three rods and sometimes they are just green trees. There symbolism can be celestial or terrestrial depending on the arrangement of rods that surround them. If there are [[number 12|twelve]] rods arranged in a [[circle]], they symbolize the celestial world, four rods forming a [[square (geometry)|square]] symbolizes the earthly world. They are always built based on the tenets of Serer symbolism, and form the family [[shrine]] devoted to the supreme being (see [[Serer ancient history]]).<ref name="Pangool pp 197-8"/>
====Creation of trees and vegetation==== =====Nqaul===== {{further|Saltigue|Lamane}} [[File:Mitragyna inermis MS 6290.jpg|thumb|right|150px|'''Nqaul''':<ref name="Nqaul">{{fr icon}} Lericollais, André, « La gestion du paysage ? Sahélisation, surexploitation et délaissement des terroirs sereer au Sénégal », Afrique de l'ouest, [[Dakar]] (21–26 November 1988), ORSTOM, [http://horizon.documentation.ird.fr/exl-doc/pleins_textes/pleins_textes_5/b_fdi_31-32/35248.pdf] For the name of Serer medicinal plants and their corresponding Latin names, see: ''Nqaul'' is spelt ''Ngaul'' (p. 8), ''Mbos'' (pp. 5 & 8), ''Somb'' (p. 8), ''Ngud'' (p. 8), ''Nalafun'' (p. 8), ''Ngol'' (p. 8), ''Saas'' is spelt ''Sas'' (p. 5), and [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:zX0dh2WfBGAJ:horizon.documentation.ird.fr/exl-doc/pleins_textes/pleins_textes_5/b_fdi_31-32/35248.pdf+nqaul+arbre&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESj_zO4iryV5DQot4rwzB5l9rtHNGpt90rXtojjfXytmdYU6-BnhVjOvjQThfX2UVLqqJP5dbcPH6Cs6LETfIBh-jn6BkD1dbw3DePJYvwGxUbxYSMXNqSZUNFrsVDWtnViGxAfE&sig=AHIEtbTGsDUtWqt0HNEu-bHo0qv9bYNagQ] (Retrieved 3 June 2012)</ref> Known by various name, its current scientific name is [[Mitragyna inermis]] and is part of [[Rubiaceae]] family of the Genus [[Mitragyna]] (2012). The barks, leaves and roots of the tree are used in many parts of [[West Africa]] for human and veterinary [[medicine]]. Found in [[Senegal]] to the [[Congo (area)|Congo]] mainly in frequently flooded [[river bank]]s and [[flood plains]].<ref>{{fr icon}} Arbonnier, M., "Arbres, arbustes et lianes des zones sèches d'Afrique de l'Ouest", CIRAD, Montpellier (2000) {{ISBN|2-87614-431-X}}</ref><ref>{{en icon}} [http://www.metafro.be/prelude/view_plant?pi=08690 "Prelude Medicinal Plant Database" (in) ''Metrafo''] (Retrieved: 3 June 2012)</ref>]]
The creation of the first [[tree]]s and [[vegetation]] are preserved in the Serer [[oral tradition]]. The [[Serer religion]] offer guidance based on the primordial seed. This has been a matter of interpretation, and such, there are competing versions as to which trees were first created and the order in which they appeared. In Serer society, [[Tree worship|trees are viewed as sacred entities]] and some trees are afforded higher religious status depending on the [[Pangool]] (the [[Reincarnation#Serer religion|ancient Serer saints and ancestral spirits]] represented by [[snakes]]) affiliated with them, their [[Serer religion#Medicine, harvest and offerings|medicinal and spiritual value to Serer]] life, etc. Some [[:Category:Serer families|Serer families]] are also associated with certain Pangool (singular: ''Fangool''). The Serer priestly class (the [[Saltigue]]s), guardians of Serer religion, sciences and ethics, still cannot agree on which tree was first created on Earth nor the order in which the first trees appeared.<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9">Gravrand, "Pangool", pp. 198−9</ref> These differences are probably due to the vast areas [[Timeline of Serer history|the proto-Serers]] once inhabited.<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/> At present, the ''Nqaul'' (proper: ''NGawul'',<ref name="Kal"/> var: ''Ngaul''<ref name="Nqaul"/> or - [[mitragyna inermis]]) and ''Nquƭ'' tree represents the [[orthodoxy|orthodox]] and prevailing Serer view,<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/> hence in the myth of Earth's creation, a [[planet]] which was supposed to have come about as a result of a primordial a [[swamp]], the ''Nqaul'' tree grew within the swamp whilst the ''Nquƭ'' grew on the [[river bank]] thereby making them the first trees on Earth according to the Serer creation mythology, with ''Nqaul'' taking precedence as it grew within the primordial swamp.<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/> In the creation myth, ''Saas'' is afforded high spiritual and medicinal status as one of the ancient trees, and form part of Serer representation of the Universe. However, it was not the original tree, and it was the tree that fell in "disgrace" after it tried to "abuse its powers".<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/>
Apart from being the first tree and linked to Earth's creation, many of the original narratives of ''Nqaul'' has been [[lost history|lost to history]]. In [[:Category:Serer country|Serer country]], it is used both as a [[medicine|medicinal]] and [[veterinary]] plant for curing various [[ailment]]s. The leaves are used against [[fever]], hypertension and to stimulate the [[intestine]]; bark [[decoction]] for [[diuretic]] and to stimulates the intestines against [[hypertension]] and fever, etc. The barks are also applied to [[wound]]s in order to improve the healing process.<ref>{{fr icon}} Potel, Anne-Marie, « Les plantes médicinales au Sénégal ». Study report of Anne-Marie Potel, accomplished at Nguekokh (Senegal), 2002. Registered in the chapter "Grey Littérature" of the PRELUDE data bank {{fr icon}} [http://pagesperso-orange.fr/senegal.bourbonnais/Anne%20marie.htm] [in] Prelude Medicinal Plant Database {{en icon}} [http://www.metafro.be/prelude/view_plant?pi=08690]</ref>
=====Nquƭ===== The ''Nquƭ'' tree (proper: ''NGuƭ'',<ref name="Kal">{{fr icon}} Kalis, Simone, "Médecine traditionnelle, religion et divination ches les Seereer Siin du Sénégal" – La connaissance de la nuit, L’Harmattan, 1997, p 291, {{ISBN|2-7384-5196-9}}</ref> variation: ''Ngud'' <ref name="Nqaul"/> - [[guiera senegalensis]]) is highly prized for its [[medicine|medicinal]] properties and is used for curing different kinds of illnesses, wounds and [[snakebite]]s. Traditional [[Saltigue|Serer healers]] specializing in snakebites often use the dried powder in their [[therapy|therapies]].<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/>
In the Serer narrative, the roots of the tree were believed to move in the [[underworld]] for survival. After the initial trees were created, then came other trees. These new trees would send their roots to the closest ''Nquƭ'' in order to feed from it before starting their [[overwintering]]. After waiting out the winter months, the nourishment they had received from the ''Nquƭ'' prior to their overwintering increased their [[trunk (botany)|trunk]] growth.<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/> At that time, trees moved and talked. They were migratory trees.<ref>A tree that has the supernatural powers to relocate from one place to another. See Thiaw, "Mythe de la création du monde selon les sages sereer"</ref> They sank deep into the underworld during the day and reappeared at night. The tree is seen as the "tree of luck and good health".<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/> In the village of ''Lang o Maak'' (now part of present-day [[Senegal]]), the tree is [[tree worship|venerated]]: ''xu'doox o'baal'' (big ''guiera senegalensis'' tree in the shape of a pot). At the time of the [[homo|ancients]], the tree appeared one night and everyone saw it. Someone tried to cut it down and he ended up dead.<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/>
The Serers believed that, all [[tree]]s are like [[human beings]] and [[animal]]s out of the same [[cosmic egg|divine placenta]] and share the same fate and destiny.<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/>
=====Saas===== The ''Saas'' tree (in [[Serer language|Serer]] and some [[Cangin languages]], var: ''Sas'') is the [[Faidherbia albida|acacia albida]] tree.
Serer advocates for ''Saas'' postulates that, the ''Saas'' is the [[tree of life]], and therefore, the [[origin of life]] on [[Earth]].<ref name="Pangool pp 125-6"/> Others reject that view, and posits that ''Saas'' was not the tree that grew within the primordial swamp and therefore, not the original tree. However, Saas is afforded religious and medicinal status useful for overall bodily health and is viewed as one of the ancient trees but not the original tree. Like the ''Nqual'' tree, many of the original narratives have been [[lost history|lost to history]]. In these contrasting views, some [[:Category:Scholars of Serer religion|scholars of Serer tradition on the origins of life]] postulates that, the ''Saas'' narrative seems to fit the wider [[West Africa]]n creation myth in terms of behaviour and judgement, and any scholar of Serer mythology on the origins of life cannot overlook the importance of ''Saas'.<ref name="Pangool pp 125-6"/><ref name="Gravrand, Henry 1971">Gravrand, Henry, "Revue de Psychopathologie africaines", Dakar (1971)</ref>
In this myth, the [[Transcendence (religion)|transcendence]] is reported to have infused with the acacia seed vital for energy, and the Saas played a pivotal role in the transmission of life.<ref name="Pangool pp 125-6"/><ref name="Gravrand, Henry 1971"/> It is believed that, the Saas was once a living tree. The narrative went on to say that, women who wanted to give birth went to it because it was considered to be a lucky tree in the wider Serer mythology and legend. Newborns were also presented to the Saas in order to bring good luck, long life, good health and prosperity to the child’s life. In similarity, if an animal went near Saas it was destined to live a long life. According to the myth, the Saas loved human beings and perhaps too much. It would sometimes lower its [[Thorns, spines, and prickles|thorny]] ends so people can [[tree hugging|give it a hug]]. Anyone who saw that immediately knew the Saas wanted their company.<ref name="Pangool pp 125-6">Pangool, pp. 125–6</ref> It did not move until [[sunset]]. It healed the wounded by its barks being rubbed on the bleeding wound. The Saas eventually became exhausting for people when it started to abuse its supernatural powers. It is generally viewed as the tree that fell in disgrace. [[Timeline of Serer history|The ancients]] called it by the name ''Nyas'', a name which has two meanings: [[scar]] or [[clot]]. The Myth of Saas still retains a certain degree of importance especially when it concerns the need for vital energy such as: during growth, at the time of marriage, in sickness and after death. It is also viewed by many as the [[fertility]] tree.<ref>Gravrand, "Pangool", p 126</ref> In the Serer representation of the Universe, the ''Myth of Saas'' forms part of the geometric diagram.
======Fertility tree====== [[File:Graves of the Sereres-1821.jpg|left|thumb|A Serer [[graveyard]] with Serer grave diggers (1821)]] The Saas is believed to possess fertilizing qualities which is concentrated in its [[green]] branches and [[moisture]]. These fertilizing components may only be abstracted by the use of its own symbol, communicated through prayer. At the birth of a child, a branch of Saas was deposited at the top of an enclosure where the child and his/her mother remains in seclusion for [[8 (number)|eight]] days (the ''Bat'' ceremony<ref>Gravrand, "Panfool", p. 231</ref>). The ritual was to ward of [[evil spirit]]s and as such, a small Saas from a [[Crossroads (mythology)|crossroad]] was chosen. The ritual demands the branch to be placed at the top of the enclosure when the child is asleep, whilst the person performing the ritual cite the appropriate prayers. A small stick of Saas is also worn on the waist by young boys and girls in order to preserve their future fertility. At weddings, a stick of the plant is deposited under the bed of the newlywed in order to improve the fertility of the couple.<ref name="Pangool, p 126-7">Pangool, p. 126−7</ref>
Saas also played a major role in [[Serer ancient history|ancient Serer]] funerals. As well as accompanying the dead with [[grave goods]], a stick of Saas was placed [[Serer religion#Mummification and Cult of the Upright Stones|inside the tomb of a dead Serer]]. The purpose of this ritual was to help the [[Spirit world (Spiritualism)|dead move on]] to ''[[Jaaniiw]]'' (the abode of souls). If this ritual was not performed, the [[soul]]s of the dead are believed to remain in the living world to the dismay of the living. A stick of Saas (with the Serer-[[viaticum]]) in their tomb helps them in their journey to the next life. When Serer men finish off burying the dead, they used to wash their hands in a [[calabash]] placed at the entrance of the house. This calabash contained branches of Saas soaked in water. Unlike the trees of the [[savannah]] that lose their leaves during the [[dry season]], the Saas is green throughout the dry and rainy seasons. In effect, the Saas was and still is considered by the Serers as a tree of life.<ref name="Pangool, p 126-7"/>
The Saas tree has an economic value to the Serers. Its dual [[economics|economic]] role benefits both the [[agriculture|agricultural]] and [[pastoral]] Serers. A Saas tree in a field of [[millet]]s increases millet production. The leaves fertilize the soil, the branches and fruit act as a sort of [[meadow]] which saves air thereby preventing Serer [[cattle|herds]] from starvation. There is also a relationship between Saas density per [[hectare]] and the demographic pressure per hectare. An abundant Saas allows [[crop rotation]] and [[intensive farming]] such as the triangular [[Diohine]]-[[Ngayokhem]]-[[Niakhar Arrondissement|Ñakhar]] (parts of [[:Category:Serer country|Serer country]]). In spite of the allegations levied against it by the ancients, many Serers still believe ''Saas'' to be the tree of life, the sacred and the [[Transcendence (religion)|transcendence]].<ref name="Pangool pp 198-9"/><ref name="Pangool, p 126-7"/>
=====Mbos===== Based on the myth of ''Mbos'' ([[Gardenia|gardenia ternifolia]]), the ''mbos'' was the first tree created by the supreme being. However, it grew and kept growing until it reached the supreme being. The creator deity got angry with it, cut off its head and said: "Tree of mbos, return to Earth". Shamed by the words of the deity, the mbos tree quickly returned to earth with its branches intertwined so that no one can climb it or pass under its shadow.<ref name="Thiaw myth"/> When Roog created the ancestors of [[modern humans]] (''maak'' - the great or elder), these ancient beings according to the myth hid under the mbos tree. After the creation of these beings, Roog created the ''dong'' (the younger). These new beings, wondered the earth trying to find the ''maak'', whom they found hidden under the mbos tree. From that day on, the mbos tree became much in demand for making [[Amulet|protective charms]].<ref name="Thiaw myth"/> In Serer symbolism, the mbos is the symbol of protection.<ref name="pan 284">Gravrand, "Pangool", p 284</ref> Mbos means [[miscarriage]]s, as in the song chanted at night by the initiates in [[Ndut initiation rite|Ndut classical teachings]]: ''Wagoxaam Mbos'' (I locked myself in the Mbos), a song with hidden meaning.<ref name="pan 284"/>
The [[Adansonia digitata|baobab tree]] (''mbudaay-baak'') also holds great religious significance among the Serers and in Serer religion. Like most revered trees in Serer mythology, before this tree can be cut (which is very rare<ref>It is a sacred tree. See Thiaw "Mythe de la création du monde selon les sages sereer"</ref>), it is customary to cite the [[incarnation]] prayer (''jat, muslaay, leemaay'') to the [[axe]] before cutting the tree down.
